title: Color Accessibility
description: Designing with color so everyone â€” including colorblind users â€” can access your work.

hook.text: 8% of men and 0.5% of women have some form of color vision deficiency. If your design relies solely on color to communicate, millions of people are locked out.

buildup.text: Common types: deuteranopia (green-blind), protanopia (red-blind), and tritanopia (blue-blind). Red-green confusion is by far the most common â€” red and green can look nearly identical.

discovery.text: The fix: never use color alone to convey information. Pair color with labels, patterns, icons, or shapes. A red error message should also have an error icon and descriptive text.

twist.text: WCAG contrast ratios (4.5:1 for text, 3:1 for large text) ensure colors are distinguishable. Tools like Stark, Color Oracle, and Sim Daltonism simulate colorblind vision so you can test your designs.

climax.text: Accessible design isn't just ethical â€” it's better design. Constraints push you toward clearer communication. When color can't do the work alone, you find stronger solutions.

punchline.text: If your design fails without color, it fails for 300 million people. Design for everyone.
